choices.text: Tracheoesophageal fistula and Tracheostomy
Tracheoesophageal fistula and Mc governs nipple
Bilateral choanal atresia and Mc governs nipple
Bilateral choanal atresia and Tracheostomy

questions.text: A newborn baby is transferred from the labor ward to the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU) due to the presence of cyanosis. During the evaluation, it is observed that the baby turns cyanotic when its mouth is closed, but the cyanosis resolves spontaneously upon crying. Based on these clinical findings, what is the most likely diagnosis and the initial management strategy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Bilateral choanal atresia and Mc governs nipple

 

Option C:

 

The bis having cyclical cyanosis and disappears on crying is suggestive of bilateral choanal atresia, the initial management is Mc governs nipple.

 

Congenital failure of the nasal cavities to open into the nasopharynx is called choanal atresia. It results from failed resorption of the buccopharyngeal membrane either unilaterally or bilaterally or even partial with a severe stenosis. As neonates are obligate nasal breathers for 6 months, bilateral choanal atresia presents immediately afterbirth with respiratory distress.

 

McGovern's nipple is a type of artificial nipple that allows for feeding while maintaining oral airway patency and would be an appropriate initial management strategy to ensure the baby can feed and breathe until definitive management, such as surgical correction, can be arranged.

 

Note - If the child doesn’t have any other serious medical problems Operative intervention is considered.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A & Option B. presents with immediate features of coughing during feeding not with features of cyclical cyanosis.

 

Option D. The initial management of Bilateral choanal atresia is Mc governs nipple not the Tracheostomy. Non-invasive measures are preferred as an initial step unless the baby's condition is such that they cannot be stabilized through less invasive means.

 

Educational objective:

 

A newborn presenting with cyanosis that resolves with crying is most likely diagnosed with bilateral choanal atresia, indicating blockage of the nasal passages. The initial management involves using a McGovern's nipple to facilitate feeding while maintaining airway patency until surgical correction can be performed.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st  Edition – Page No-8616-8618.

choices.text: Atropic Rhinitis
Nasal polyposis
Foreign body
Septal deviation.

questions.text: A 3-year-old, previously healthy child, is brought to the clinic by their mother due to a complaint of foul-smelling discharge from the left side of the nose. Examination reveals unilateral nasal obstruction and a foul-smelling discharge. Upon further examination, an object is seen in the nasal cavity, as shown in the image. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Foreign body

 

Option C:

 

  • Unilateral nasal obstruction with foul-smelling discharge is the classic presentation of retained foreign body in the nose in young children.
  • TH child may present with features of bleeding per nose.
  • The examination with nasal speculum and removal by endoscope is advised.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Atrophic Rhinitis: This is a chronic condition characterized by atrophy of the nasal mucosa and is uncommon in young children.

 

Option B. Nasal Polyposis: Nasal polyps are typically bilateral and not usually associated with a foul smell. They are also rare in this age group.

 

Option D. Septal Deviation: This structural issue typically does not cause a foul-smelling discharge and is usually not diagnosed in such young children unless associated with trauma or congenital malformation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key indicators of a nasal foreign body include unilateral nasal obstruction, foul-smelling discharge, and the visualization of an object in the nasal cavity. Prompt recognition and removal of the foreign body are essential to prevent complications such as infection and further obstruction.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition page no 8739-8744

choices.text: Parainfluenza virus and dexamethasone
Respiratory syncytial virus and epinephrine
Respiratory syncytial virus and dexamethasone
Hemophilus influenza and epinephrine

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the pediatric outpatient department with symptoms of low-grade fever, coughing, and stridor. The child is stable upon assessment. An X-ray shows narrowing of the glottis. What is the most common cause of this condition in children and the drug of choice (DOC) for its management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Parainfluenza virus and dexamethasone

 

Option A:

 

The presentation is indicative of croup, an upper airway infection that often leads to a "seal-like" barking cough and stridor. Croup is most commonly caused by the parainfluenza virus. Dexamethasone is the DOC because of its effectiveness in reducing airway inflammation and edema, which can alleviate symptoms and prevent progression to more severe illness.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) and epinephrine: RSV is a common cause of lower respiratory tract infections such as bronchiolitis, especially in infants and not typically associated with glottic narrowing seen in croup. Epinephrine is used for rapid relief of airway obstruction in moderate to severe croup but is not the primary cause of the condition.

 

Option C. Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) and dexamethasone: While dexamethasone is used for croup, RSV is less commonly associated with croup and more with bronchiolitis.

 

Option D. Haemophilus influenzae and epinephrine: Haemophilus influenzae, especially type b (Hib), can cause epiglottitis, a condition that also presents with stridor but is more severe and life-threatening than croup. Epinephrine would not be the DOC for epiglottitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute laryngotracheobronchitis/ Croup (Mc in children age-6 months to 5yrs)

Caused by-parainfluenza virus.

 

  • The onset of illness is gradual, mild cold for few days then brassy cough and mild inspiratory stridor.
  • Severe croup: restless, anxious (due to hypoxemia), eventually cyanosis
  • Diagnosis: narrowing of glottis/subglottis, trachea, bronchi.
  • Management: symptomatic treatment for fever and encouraging child to take liquids orally
  • DOC: dexamethasone (corticosteroids) -intramuscular (0.3-0.6 mg/kg)
  • Severe croup: hospitalization, intensive care with oxygen inhalation and nebulized epinephrine.

 

Ref: Ghai essential paediatrics-8th edition page 377

choices.text: Situs inversus
Situs solitus
Chronic sinusitis
Bronchiectasis

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother, who reports that her son has been suffering from recurrent respiratory infections since infancy. She is concerned because these infections seem to be more severe and frequent compared to his peers. On physical examination, you note a productive cough and auscultate crackles in the lower lobes bilaterally. The child also has a history of chronic ear and sinus infections. You decide to order a chest X-ray, as the report shown below. Given the clinical presentation and the X-ray findings, you suspect an autosomal recessive disorder involving a mutation in the dynein protein. Which of the following is NOT part of the classic triad of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Situs solitus

 

Option B:

 

Situs solitus describes viscera that are in the normal position, with the stomach on the left side; in situs inversus, the positions of heart is reversed.

 

Explanation:

 

Kartagener's syndrome is a rare, autosomal recessive genetic ciliary disorder comprising the triad of Situs Inversus (Option A), Chronic Sinusitis (Option C), and Bronchiectasis (Option D). The basic problem lies in the defective movement of cilia, leading to recurrent chest infections, ear/nose/throat symptoms, and infertility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kartagener’s syndrome is a subset of primary ciliary dyskinesia. The classic triad of Kartagener's syndrome includes situs inversus, chronic sinusitis, and bronchiectasis. Chronic sinusitis and bronchiectasis are due to defects in ciliary action, which is impaired due to the dynein protein mutation.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition –Chapter - 433 Page No-From 9606

choices.text: Administer a first dose of antibiotic and wait for the culture report.
Administer a first dose of antiviral and wait for the culture report.
Wait and watch .
Establish a proper airway for the child.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the emergency department by their mother, who reports that the child has had a fever for the past 2 days. Since the morning, the child has been unable to eat or drink water, exhibiting significant drooling of saliva and dysphagia. Upon examination, the child appears toxic and is found to have an inspiratory stridor. Given these clinical findings, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Establish a proper airway for the child

 

Option D:

 

The child has features of acute epiglottitis/ Supraglottitis.

 

Supraglottitis is a cellulitis of the tissues comprising the laryngeal inlet. It has become exceedingly rare since the introduction of conjugate Hib vaccines. Direct bacterial invasion of the involved tissues is probably the initiating pathophysiologic event. This dramatic, potentially lethal condition can occur at any age. Because of the risk of sudden, unpredictable airway obstruction.

 

Establishing a proper airway for the child is the first line Immediately securing airway is paramount and should not be delayed pending investigations. After securing airway by intubation, we can start IV fluids, IV antibiotics and perform necessary investigations to confirm the diagnosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Administer a first dose of antibiotic and wait for the culture report: While antibiotics are critical in the treatment of bacterial infections, the immediate concern in a child with airway obstruction symptoms is to secure the airway. Antibiotic therapy should be initiated after airway stabilization.

 

Option B. Administer a first dose of antiviral and wait for the culture report: Antiviral medications are not the first-line treatment for acute airway obstructions, which are more commonly caused by bacterial infections in pediatric cases. The priority should be airway management.

 

Option C. Wait and watch: This approach is contraindicated in a child with signs of airway obstruction and a toxic appearance, as it can lead to rapid deterioration and respiratory arrest.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Supraglottitis is a medical emergency. Establishing an airway by endotracheal or nasotracheal intubation or, less often, by tracheostomy is first line of management. Antimicrobial therapy directed against H. influenzae and other etiologic agents should be administered parenterally, and therapy should be continued until patients are able to take fluids by mouth. The duration of antimicrobial therapy is typically 7 days.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition- Chapter 412, pg 6010, 8707

choices.text: Epiglottitis and Strep pneumoniae
Tracheobronchitis and H. influenzae
Tracheobronchitis and Parainfluenza virus
Epiglottitis and H influenzae

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the clinic by their mother due to a 4-day history of fever and noisy breathing, which has recently been accompanied by coughing. The symptoms have increased the mother's concern. Upon examination, the child is found to have an inspiratory stridor. An X-ray is performed, showing the image provided. Based on the clinical presentation and the X-ray findings, what is the likely diagnosis and the most common causative agent in a child who has been immunized?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Tracheobronchitis and Parainfluenza virus

 

Option C:

 

The diagnosis based on the history and X ray findings are Tracheobronchitis and is most commonly caused by Parainfluenza virus.

 

Croup, also known as laryngotracheobronchitis, is a type of respiratory infection that is usually caused by the parainfluenza virus. The infection leads to swelling inside the trachea, which interferes with normal breathing and produces the classic symptoms of "barking/brassy" cough, inspiratory stridor, and a hoarse voice. Fever and runny nose may also be present.

 

“Steeple sign” suggestive of subglottic narrowing, seen in case of croup or Tracheobronchitis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Epiglottitis and Streptococcus pneumoniae: Epiglottitis typically presents with a high fever, severe sore throat, drooling, and difficulty swallowing, with a child appearing much more toxic than one with croup. Streptococcus pneumoniae is more commonly associated with pneumonia and not a primary cause of epiglottitis.

 

Option B. Tracheobronchitis and Haemophilus influenzae: While H. influenzae can cause respiratory tract infections, the widespread use of the Hib vaccine has made it an unlikely cause of tracheobronchitis in an immunized child. Additionally, tracheobronchitis caused by bacteria would typically present with more severe systemic symptoms.

 

Option D. Epiglottitis and Haemophilus influenzae: This used to be a common pairing before the Hib vaccine became widespread. Epiglottitis presents with a high fever, drooling, difficulty swallowing, and a muffled voice, along with a characteristic "thumb sign" on lateral neck X-ray, not the steeple sign seen in croup.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fever, noisy breathing, and inspiratory stridor, show a "steeple sign" on X-ray, is diagnosed as croup (tracheobronchitis), commonly caused by the Parainfluenza virus in immunized children.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition –Chapter - 412 Page No-From 8702

choices.text: Intubation with mechanical ventilation
Dexamethasone administration
Antibiotic administration
Epinephrine nebulization

questions.text: A mother brings her 11-year-old child with complaints of fever, cough and difficulty in breathing for 5 days. On evaluation an inspiratory stridor along with a cough which resembles like barking was noted. The vitals of the child were stable. X rays reveals a subglottic narrowing. All of the following can be used in the management of this patient except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Antibiotic administration.

  • This is a classical case of Croup
  • Tracheobronchitis, and is most commonly caused by Parainfluenza virus.
  • “Steeple sign” suggestive of subglottic narrowing, seen in case of croup or Tracheobronchitis.
  • Treatment include; Dexamethasone administration with Epinephrine nebulization.
  • Intubation with mechanical ventilation can be done in sever cases.

 

Option A, B and D can be done case of croup, As it’s caused by virus, there is no significant role of antibiotics in it.

 

Ref; Nelson 20th Edition – Page No- 2032-2034/ Ghai 9th Edition - Page No-373-377

choices.text: Acute laryngitis
Acute tonsillitis
Acute epiglottitis
Acute pharyngitis

questions.text: A mother brings her 6-year-old child presenting with complaints of high fever, severe sore throat, difficulty swallowing, drooling, and inspiratory stridor. On examination, the child appears anxious, has a muffled voice, and the following appearance. Based on these findings given, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Acute epiglottitis

 

Option C:

 

The most likely diagnosis in this case is Acute epiglottitis. The presence of high fever, severe sore throat, difficulty swallowing, drooling, and inspiratory stridor, along with an anxious appearance, muffled voice, and a cherry-red epiglottis in the image are all consistent with acute epiglottitis.

 

  • Acute epiglottitis is a serious medical emergency that requires immediate treatment to prevent airway obstruction and respiratory failure.
  • Treatment of acute epiglottitis involves immediate airway management, such as intubation or tracheostomy, to maintain airway patency.
  • Antibiotics are also administered to treat the underlying bacterial infection causing the epiglottitis.
  • It is important to note that the use of oral examination or throat swab to diagnose acute epiglottitis should be avoided due to the risk of airway obstruction due to LARYNGOSPASM.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acute laryngitis presents with hoarseness, cough, and mild throat pain, but lacks the characteristic symptoms and physical findings seen in acute epiglottitis.

 

Option B. Acute tonsillitis presents with sore throat, fever, and enlarged tonsils, but lacks the inspiratory stridor and cherry-red epiglottis.

 

Option D. Acute pharyngitis presents with sore throat, fever, and enlarged lymph nodes, but lacks the drooling, inspiratory stridor, and cherry-red epiglottis seen in acute epiglottitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute epiglottitis, a potentially life-threatening condition characterized by rapid onset of high fever, severe sore throat, difficulty swallowing, drooling, inspiratory stridor, anxious appearance, and the presence of a "thumb sign" on lateral neck X-rays. Prompt recognition and management are essential to prevent airway compromise and respiratory distress.

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition page 8702
